notes.text:
An update for httpd is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Moderate. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
The httpd packages provide the Apache HTTP Server, a powerful, efficient, and extensible web server.

The following packages have been upgraded to a later upstream version: httpd (2.4.53). (BZ#2079939)

Security Fix(es):

* httpd: mod_sed: Read/write beyond bounds (CVE-2022-23943)

* httpd: mod_lua: Use of uninitialized value of in r:parsebody (CVE-2022-22719)

* httpd: core: Possible buffer overflow with very large or unlimited LimitXMLRequestBody (CVE-2022-22721)

* httpd: mod_proxy_ajp: Possible request smuggling (CVE-2022-26377)

* httpd: mod_lua: DoS in r:parsebody (CVE-2022-29404)

* httpd: mod_sed: DoS vulnerability (CVE-2022-30522)

* httpd: mod_proxy: X-Forwarded-For dropped by hop-by-hop mechanism (CVE-2022-31813)

* httpd: Out-of-bounds read via ap_rwrite() (CVE-2022-28614)

* httpd: Out-of-bounds read in ap_strcmp_match() (CVE-2022-28615)

* httpd: mod_lua: Information disclosure with websockets (CVE-2022-30556)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.

Additional Changes:

For detailed information on changes in this release, see the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9.1 Release Notes linked from the References section.
notes.title: Details

document.title: Red Hat Security Advisory: httpd security, bug fix, and enhancement update

notes.text: A flaw was found in the mod_lua module of httpd. A crafted request body can cause a read to a random memory area due to an uninitialized value in functions called by the parsebody function. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to system availability.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: httpd: mod_lua: Use of uninitialized value of in r:parsebody
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: httpd as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6, is not affected by this flaw because it does not ship mod_lua.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.
Disabling mod_lua and restarting httpd will mitigate this flaw. See https://access.redhat.com/articles/10649 for more information.

vulnerabilities.title: httpd: mod_lua: Use of uninitialized value of in r:parsebody

notes.text: A flaw was found in httpd, where it incorrectly limits the value of the LimitXMLRequestBody option. This issue can lead to an integer overflow and later causes an out-of-bounds write.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: httpd: core: Possible buffer overflow with very large or unlimited LimitXMLRequestBody
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The default configuration of the LimitXMLRequestBody option on RHEL is 1MB and therefore is not vulnerable to this flaw. Also, this issue is known to only affect 32bit httpd builds.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.

Set the LimitXMLRequestBody option to a value smaller than 350MB. Setting it to 0 is not recommended as it will use a hard limit (depending on 32bit or 64bit systems) which may result in an overall system out-of-memory. The default configuration is not vulnerable to this flaw, see the statement above.

vulnerabilities.title: httpd: core: Possible buffer overflow with very large or unlimited LimitXMLRequestBody

notes.text: An out-of-bounds read/write vulnerability was found in the mod_sed module of httpd. This flaw allows an attacker to overwrite the memory of an httpd instance that is using mod_sed with data provided by the attacker.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: httpd: mod_sed: Read/write beyond bounds
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The `mod_sed` module is disabled by default on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 and 8. For this reason, the flaw has been rated as having a security impact of Moderate. The httpd package as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 is not affected by this flaw because the `mod_sed` module is available only in httpd 2.3 and later.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.
Disabling mod_sed and restarting httpd will mitigate this flaw. See https://access.redhat.com/articles/10649 for more information.

cwe.name: Inconsistent Interpretation of HTTP Requests ('HTTP Request/Response Smuggling')

notes.text: An HTTP request smuggling vulnerability was found in the mod_proxy_ajp module of httpd. This flaw allows an attacker to smuggle requests to the AJP server, where it forwards requests.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: httpd: mod_proxy_ajp: Possible request smuggling
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The httpd mod_proxy_ajp module is enabled by default on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8, 9, and in RHSCL. However, there are no directives forwarding requests using the AJP protocol.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.
Disabling mod_proxy_ajp and restarting httpd will mitigate this flaw.

cwe.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor

notes.text: An out-of-bounds read vulnerability was found in httpd. A very large input to the ap_rputs and ap_rwrite functions can lead to an integer overflow and result in an out-of-bounds read.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: httpd: Out-of-bounds read via ap_rwrite()
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.

notes.text: An out-of-bounds read vulnerability was found in httpd. A very large input to the ap_strcmp_match function can lead to an integer overflow and result in an out-of-bounds read.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: httpd: Out-of-bounds read in ap_strcmp_match()
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: According to upstream, no code distributed with the httpd server can exploit this flaw, however, third-party modules or Lua scripts that use the ap_strcmp_match function could potentially be affected.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.

cwe.name: Allocation of Resources Without Limits or Throttling

notes.text: A flaw was found in the mod_lua module of httpd. A malicious request to a Lua script that calls parsebody(0) can lead to a denial of service due to no default limit on the possible input size.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: httpd: mod_lua: DoS in r:parsebody
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: httpd as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6, is not affected by this flaw because it does not ship mod_lua.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.
Disabling mod_lua and restarting httpd will mitigate this flaw.

cwe.name: Memory Allocation with Excessive Size Value

notes.text: A flaw was found in the mod_sed module of httpd. A very large input to the mod_sed module can result in a denial of service due to excessively large memory allocations.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: httpd: mod_sed: DoS vulnerability
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The mod_sed module is disabled by default on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 and 8. The httpd package as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 is not affected by this flaw because the mod_sed module is not available.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.
Disabling mod_sed and restating httpd will mitigate this flaw.

cwe.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor

notes.text: A flaw was found in the mod_lua module of httpd. The data returned by the wsread function may point past the end of the storage allocated for the buffer, resulting in information disclosure.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: httpd: mod_lua: Information disclosure with websockets
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: httpd as shipped with Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6, is not affected by this flaw because it does not ship mod_lua. Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 is not affected by this flaw because the wsread function is not available.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.
Disabling mod_lua and restarting httpd will mitigate this flaw.

vulnerabilities.title: httpd: mod_lua: Information disclosure with websockets

notes.text: A flaw was found in the mod_proxy module of httpd. The server may remove the X-Forwarded-* headers from a request based on the client-side Connection header hop-by-hop mechanism.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: httpd: mod_proxy: X-Forwarded-For dropped by hop-by-hop mechanism
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: This flaw has been rated as having a security impact of Moderate, and is not currently planned to be addressed in future updates of Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7. Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 is now in Maintenance Support 2 Phase of the support and maintenance life cycle. For additional information, refer to the Red Hat Enterprise Linux Life Cycle: https://access.redhat.com/support/policy/updates/errata.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

After installing the updated packages, the httpd daemon will be restarted automatically.

Mitigation for this issue is either not available or the currently available options do not meet the Red Hat Product Security criteria comprising ease of use and deployment, applicability to widespread installation base or stability.

vulnerabilities.title: httpd: mod_proxy: X-Forwarded-For dropped by hop-by-hop mechanism
